EXECUTIVE SUMMARY:



Verso Corporation (Verso) is committed to operating in a manner that is safe for facility employees, the public, and the environment.  As part of this commitment, the Androscoggin Mill has established a system to ensure safe operation of the processes at the facility.   One component of this system is the Risk Management Program (RMP) that aids in the management of hazardous chemical safety in the mill; in compliance with the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions, 40 CFR Part 68.  One of the requirement of the RMP rule is to submit a risk management plan (RMPlan), describing the risk management program at the mill. This document is intended to satisfy the RMPlan requirement of the RMP rule and to provide the public with a description of the rule as it applies to the mill.



The RMPlan was originally submitted on June 21, 1999 and this information was shared with the public at a meeting with the town of Jay on January 13, 2000.  



The risk management program at the mill consists of three elements:

1. A hazard assessment to help understand (a) the potential off-site consequences of hypothetical accidental releases; and (b) accidents that have occurred during the last five years associated with the use of RMP regulated substances (chlorine dioxide and ammonia).



2. A prevention program to help maintain and safely operate the processes containing more than a threshold quantity of a regulated substance (covered process).



3. An emergency response program to help respond to accidental releases of regulated substances from the covered process.



Verso limits the use of hazardous substances.  Before using a hazardous substance at the mill, less hazardous alternatives are considered.  Considerations are taken with also the existing chemicals on site.  For example, chlorine and methanol have been replaced with alternative, non-RMP covered chemicals.



When a hazardous substance is used at the mill, the eq

uipment has been designed, built, and operated to reduce the likelihood of an accidental release of the chemical.  Industry and government standards are closely adhered to in the design, construction, and operation of the process; including studying all safety aspects of the process through the Hazard and Operability studies (HazOps) and in the case of chlorine dioxide, following the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard, 29 CFR 1910.119.



The mill is committed to the safety of the workers and the public, as well as the preservation of the environment, through the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances.  In the event of an accidental release, the mill controls and contains the release in a manner that will be safe for workers as well as minimize impact to the public or the environment.  Verso provides training to all personnel, has a designated emergency response coordinator to oversee response activities, and coordinated response efforts with the local fire department.  These response activities are documented and discussed with the LEPC.



A single-vessel process (SVP) onsite generates an aqueous solution of chlorine dioxide for the bleaching process at the mill. The aqueous chloring dioxide has a maximum concentration of approximately 12.5 g/L (approximately 1.25%) and is pumped into two aboveground storage tanks each with a maximum capacity of 240,000-gallons (approximately 25,158 lbs.). In 1992, the mill began a formal prevention program for the chlorine dioxide generation and storage processes. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the Verso prevention program that address the EPA and OSHA requirements.



Program Level 3 Prevention Program:  The program level 3 prevention plan applies to the chlorine dioxide generation and storage processes, consists of the following elements:



1. Process Safety Information

2. Process Hazards Analysis

3. Operation Procedures

4

. Training (Operation & Maintenance)

5. Mechanical Integrity

6. Management of Change

7. Pre-Startup Safety Review

8. Compliance Audit

9. Incident Investigation

10. Employee Participation

11. Hot Works Permits

12. Contractor Requirements

13. Emergency response



Verso acquired the cogeneration plant in 2007.  The cogeneration facility uses a 28% aqueous ammonia solution for Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) during the combustion of natural gas in the turbine. Aqueous ammonia at concentrations of 20% or greater is listed as a program level 2 chemical under the RMP rule.



Program Level 2 Prevention Plan:  The program level 2 prevention plan applies to the aqueous ammonia storage process and consists of the following elements:  



1. Hazards Review

2. Operating Procedures

3. Training

4. Maintenance

5. Management of Change

6. Compliance Audits

7. Incident Investigation



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no release incidents that have affected the surrounding community in the past five years.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



Verso has developed a written emergency response program to aid in the response to accidental releases of hazardous substances.  The emergency response plan includes procedures for:



1. Informing the local fire department and the public about accidental releases that could reasonably result in off-site consequences.

2. Providing proper first aid and emergency medical treatment to treat accidental human exposure to hazardous substances at the mill

3. Controlling and containing accidental releases of hazardous substances, including the use of emergency response equipment.

4. Inspecting and maintaining emergency response equipment.

5. Reviewing and updating the emergency response plan.



The mill maintains an emergency response team trained in these emergency response procedures. All mill employees are trained in evacuation procedures. The mill periodically conducts emergency response drills, including annual dri

lls that may be coordinated with the local fire department, police department, and the state and local emergency planning commissions.



The written emergency response plan complies with other federal contingency plan regulations and has been communicated to local emergency response officials through the local fire department.  The mill maintains a regular dialogue with the local fire chief, and Verso provides appropriate information to the fire chief.
